description.short: Measures vulnerability created when organizations unconsciously adopt either aggressive defensive stances (fight) or complete avoidance behaviors (flight) when facing cybersecurity threats
description.context: Fight-flight security postures occur when organizations unconsciously adopt either aggressive defensive stances (fight) or complete avoidance behaviors (flight) when facing cybersecurity threats. This creates systematic blind spots where organizations either over-invest in perimeter defenses while ignoring internal threats, or avoid security decisions entirely through denial and delegation. These reactive patterns bypass rational risk assessment and create predictable vulnerabilities that attackers can exploit.
description.impact: Organizations with high fight-flight vulnerability experience insider threat blindness from over-focus on external perimeters, alert fatigue amplification from aggressive monitoring creating noise that obscures genuine threats, or security avoidance leading to delayed threat investigation. Historical incidents include organizations implementing aggressive DLP solutions that block legitimate business while missing subtle data exfiltration, and executive teams avoiding security briefings until after breaches occur.
description.psychological_basis: Bion's Basic Assumption Fight-Flight (baF) - a pre-conscious group dynamic where organizations unconsciously adopt binary defensive stances when facing threats. This psychological mechanism operates below rational decision-making threshold, typically activating within 300-500ms of threat perception. LeDoux (2000) demonstrates that amygdala activation (threat response) occurs before prefrontal cortex engagement (rational analysis), explaining why organizations default to fight-flight postures before implementing structured security frameworks.

scoring.formula: Final_Score = (w1 Ã— Quick_Assessment + w2 Ã— Conversation_Depth + w3 Ã— Red_Flags) Ã— Interdependency_Multiplier

green.label: Low Vulnerability - Resilient
green.description: Balanced security investments (40-60% internal vs perimeter), security decisions made within 5 business days, exception rate below 10% with documented process, evidence-based investment decisions, alert investigation rate above 80%, constructive executive security discussions.

yellow.label: Moderate Vulnerability - Developing
yellow.description: Moderately imbalanced investments (30-70% split), security decisions take 1-2 weeks, exception rate 10-25% with informal approvals, mixed rational/reactive investment decisions, alert investigation rate 50-80%, inconsistent executive engagement.

red.label: High Vulnerability - Critical
red.description: Severely imbalanced investments (over 70% perimeter or under 30% internal), security decisions delayed over 2 weeks or made hastily under pressure, exception rate above 25%, purely reactive investment decisions, alert investigation rate below 50%, executives avoid security discussions.

fight_response_index.description: Measures over-reactive defensive postures relative to actual threats

flight_response_index.description: Measures security avoidance and delegation patterns

variables.Avoidance_Behaviors: count of deferred decisions, delayed investigations, ignored alerts
variables.Security_Requirements: total security actions required in time period

balance_index.description: Measures imbalance in security investment allocation
balance_index.interpretation: Higher values indicate fight-flight driven investment rather than balanced risk management

temporal_decay.description: Exponential smoothing with 1.5-hour time constant for fight-flight pattern detection

posture_classification.formula: Posture = 'fight' if FRI > FLI AND BI > 0.3, 'flight' if FLI > FRI AND BI > 0.3, else 'balanced'
posture_classification.description: Classify organizational security posture based on behavioral patterns

FRI.calculation: Ratio of defensive actions to actual threat detections multiplied by aggression level
FRI.query: SELECT (COUNT(action_type='defensive') / COUNT(threat_detected=true)) * AVG(aggression_score) FROM security_events WHERE time_window='24h'

FLI.calculation: Ratio of avoidance behaviors to security requirements
FLI.query: SELECT (COUNT(status='deferred' OR status='ignored') / COUNT(*)) * AVG(withdrawal_score) FROM security_requirements WHERE timestamp > NOW() - INTERVAL '7 days'

BI.calculation: Investment imbalance between perimeter and internal security
BI.query: SELECT ABS(SUM(CASE WHEN category='perimeter' THEN amount ELSE 0 END) - SUM(CASE WHEN category='internal' THEN amount ELSE 0 END)) / SUM(amount) FROM security_spending WHERE fiscal_year=current

sections.title: QUICK ASSESSMENT

items.title: Security Budget Allocation Balance
items.question: In the past 12 months, what percentage of your cybersecurity budget was spent on perimeter security (firewalls, intrusion detection, network monitoring) versus internal security (endpoint protection, access controls, data loss prevention)? Tell us your specific budget breakdown.

options.label: Balanced allocation: 40-60% split between perimeter and internal security with documented risk-based justification
Moderate imbalance: 30-70% split showing preference for one domain but some investment in both
Severe imbalance: Over 70% in perimeter or under 30% in internal security showing fight or flight pattern

items.evidence_required: Security budget breakdown by domain (perimeter, internal, response), investment justification documentation

items.title: Security Decision Response Time
items.question: When a potential security threat is identified, how long does it typically take your organization to make a decision about response actions? Walk us through a recent example of threat response decision-making.

options.label: Timely balanced response: Security decisions completed within 5 business days with documented assessment
Delayed response: Security decisions take 1-2 weeks with some reactive pressure
Extreme patterns: Either hasty decisions made under pressure without assessment OR prolonged delays over 2 weeks avoiding decisions

items.evidence_required: Threat response timeline documentation, decision-making process records, recent examples

items.title: Security Policy Exception Rate
items.question: How often do security policy exceptions get approved, and what's the typical approval process? Give us a specific example of a recent security exception request and how it was handled.

options.label: Controlled exceptions: Below 10% exception rate with documented approval process and regular review
Moderate exceptions: 10-25% exception rate with informal approval process
Excessive exceptions: Above 25% rate OR no tracking of exception frequency

items.evidence_required: Security exception logs for past 6 months, approval workflow documentation, specific examples

items.title: Security Investment Decision Triggers
items.question: Describe your last major security investment decision. What triggered the decision, who was involved, and how long did the process take from initial discussion to implementation?

options.label: Evidence-based: Security investments based on risk assessment, multiple stakeholder input, systematic evaluation
Mixed approach: Some evidence-based decisions but also reactive responses to incidents or pressure
Purely reactive: Security investments triggered by incidents, audits, or executive pressure without systematic planning

items.evidence_required: Investment decision documentation, risk assessment records, decision timeline
items.soc_mapping: Investment trigger analysis from financial and decision tracking systems

items.title: Security Alert Investigation Rate
items.question: When security tools generate alerts or recommendations, what percentage typically get investigated within 48 hours? Tell us about a recent week's alert handling.

options.label: High investigation rate: Above 80% of alerts investigated within 48 hours with documented outcomes
Moderate investigation rate: 50-80% investigation within 48 hours, some backlogs
Low investigation rate: Below 50% investigation OR significant alert fatigue from over-aggressive monitoring

items.evidence_required: SIEM alert statistics for past month, investigation completion records, specific weekly example

items.title: Executive Security Discussion Quality
items.question: How does your organization handle security discussions in executive meetings? Describe the typical reaction when security issues are raised and provide a recent example.

options.label: Constructive engagement: Executives actively participate in security discussions, regular briefings, balanced decision-making
Inconsistent engagement: Variable executive participation, sometimes constructive, sometimes avoidant
Problematic patterns: Executives avoid security discussions, react defensively, or make hasty decisions under pressure

items.evidence_required: Executive meeting minutes with security topics, briefing schedules, engagement examples
items.soc_mapping: Executive engagement patterns from meeting records and communication analysis

items.title: Security-Business Conflict Resolution
items.question: What happens when security measures conflict with business operations? Give us a specific example of how such conflicts were resolved in the past 6 months.

options.label: Structured resolution: Formal process for resolving conflicts within defined timeframes, risk acceptance documentation
Ad-hoc resolution: Conflicts resolved case-by-case without consistent process
Security disabled: Conflicts typically resolved by disabling security controls or indefinitely deferring security requirements

items.evidence_required: Conflict resolution documentation, risk acceptance logs, specific conflict examples
items.soc_mapping: Conflict resolution patterns from exception and decision tracking

sections.instructions: Select ONE option for each question. Each answer contributes to the weighted final score. Evidence should be documented for audit trail.

items.text: Walk me through your security budget allocation. What percentage goes to perimeter security versus internal controls, and how did you arrive at this distribution?

scoring_guidance.green: Balanced 40-60% split with documented risk assessment justifying allocation decisions
scoring_guidance.yellow: Imbalanced allocation (30-70%) with some awareness but rationalized as 'industry standard' or 'vendor recommended'
scoring_guidance.red: Severe imbalance (>70% one domain) with fight posture ('we need strong perimeter') or flight posture ('internal controls too complex') language

followups.text: What specific risk assessment led to this investment distribution?
When was the last time you questioned whether this balance was appropriate?

items.text: Describe your most recent major security investment. What triggered it, and how quickly did you move from decision to implementation?

scoring_guidance.green: Evidence-based decision with systematic evaluation, multiple stakeholders, reasonable timeline with documented phases
scoring_guidance.yellow: Mix of rational planning and reactive pressure, compressed timeline but some evaluation
scoring_guidance.red: Purely reactive trigger (breach, audit finding, executive mandate) with rushed implementation bypassing evaluation

followups.text: What alternatives did you consider before making this investment?
Looking back, do you feel the decision process was appropriate or driven by pressure?

items.text: Tell me about your security alert volume and investigation process. What percentage of alerts get investigated, and what's your false positive rate?

scoring_guidance.green: 80%+ investigation rate with <20% false positives, systematic triage process, documented outcomes
scoring_guidance.yellow: 50-80% investigation with 20-40% false positives, some backlog but active management
scoring_guidance.red: Either <50% investigation (flight pattern: avoidance) OR excessive false positives >40% (fight pattern: over-aggressive monitoring)

followups.text: Walk me through what happened with last week's security alerts.
How does your team feel about the alert volume and quality?

items.text: When a potential threat is detected, what's your typical decision-making timeline from detection to response action?

scoring_guidance.green: Systematic response within 5 business days with documented decision framework and stakeholder input
scoring_guidance.yellow: Variable timelines (1-2 weeks) with some reactive pressure affecting consistency
scoring_guidance.red: Either hasty decisions under pressure without assessment OR prolonged delays (>2 weeks) avoiding difficult decisions

followups.text: Give me a specific example from the past month with actual timelines.
What factors cause deviations from your standard response timeline?

items.text: How do executives engage with security discussions? Walk me through what typically happens when you present security issues in leadership meetings.

scoring_guidance.green: Constructive engagement with regular briefings, balanced questions, evidence-based decisions, supportive culture
scoring_guidance.yellow: Variable engagement depending on context, sometimes constructive but sometimes rushed or avoidant
scoring_guidance.red: Pattern of avoidance (flight: deferring discussions, cutting briefings short) OR hasty reactive decisions (fight: mandate immediate action without assessment)

followups.text: Describe the last security briefing you gave to executives and their specific reactions.
How comfortable are you bringing bad security news to leadership?

items.text: When security requirements conflict with business needs, how are these conflicts typically resolved?

scoring_guidance.green: Structured resolution process with risk assessment, documented trade-offs, compensating controls, regular review
scoring_guidance.yellow: Ad-hoc resolution with inconsistent approaches depending on who's involved
scoring_guidance.red: Consistent pattern of security being disabled (flight) OR business operations being blocked (fight) without proper risk analysis

followups.text: Give me a specific example from the past 6 months of such a conflict and how it was resolved.
How many permanent security exceptions exist in your environment and why?

subsections.title: Probing for Red Flags
subsections.description: Observable indicators that increase vulnerability score regardless of stated policies

items.label: "We need to be more aggressive about security, lock everything down..." (Fight pattern)
"Security is too complex, we can't deal with that right now..." (Flight pattern)
"After that breach, we're treating everyone as a threat..." (Fight overreaction)
"The alerts are overwhelming, we can't keep up..." (Fight leading to fatigue)
"We'll deal with security after this busy period..." (Flight avoidance)
"Security keeps blocking business, so we have to bypass it..." (Flight via exceptions)
"We just bought a new security tool, that should fix it..." (Flight via technology substitution)

solutions.title: Balanced Security Architecture Review
solutions.description: Conduct quarterly reviews of security spending allocation using standardized framework mandating minimum percentages for different security domains
solutions.implementation: Establish investment targets: 30-40% perimeter, 35-45% internal, 15-25% response/recovery. Create executive dashboards showing investment balance with clear justifications for any deviations from target allocations. Implement systematic rebalancing when thresholds exceeded.
solutions.technical_controls: Budget tracking system with automated alerts for allocation deviations, dashboard visualization of investment balance, quarterly review workflow

solutions.title: Security Decision Framework Implementation
solutions.description: Deploy structured decision-making process with defined timelines counteracting emotional decision-making
solutions.implementation: Establish decision SLAs: 72-hour initial assessment, 5-day decision deadline, escalation procedures for delays. Include decision criteria matrices weighing business impact, threat likelihood, implementation complexity, and resource requirements to counteract fight-flight responses.
solutions.technical_controls: Decision tracking workflow system, automated timeline monitoring, decision quality scorecards, escalation automation

solutions.title: Alert Management Optimization
solutions.description: Implement tiered alert prioritization with automated initial triage and mandatory response timeframes
solutions.implementation: Deploy alert tiers (critical/high/medium/low) with specific investigation SLAs. Implement automated initial triage reducing analyst burden. Track false positive rates and analyst burnout indicators. Regular tuning cycles to optimize alert quality.
solutions.technical_controls: SIEM alert tuning automation, alert fatigue monitoring dashboard, investigation queue management, quality metrics tracking

solutions.title: Executive Security Briefing Protocol
solutions.description: Establish monthly structured security briefings using standardized formats that present balanced risk information
solutions.implementation: Create briefing templates including both threat landscape updates and security program achievements to maintain constructive engagement. Train security leaders in presenting balanced risk information that doesn't trigger fight-flight responses. Establish regular cadence preventing avoidance patterns.
solutions.technical_controls: Briefing template library, presentation effectiveness metrics, executive engagement tracking, feedback loops

solutions.title: Conflict Resolution Process
solutions.description: Create formal procedures for resolving security-business conflicts within defined timeframes
solutions.implementation: Establish conflict resolution SLAs, risk acceptance documentation requirements, compensating controls identification process, and regular review of temporary exceptions to prevent permanent security degradation. Include mediation process for escalated conflicts.
solutions.technical_controls: Conflict tracking system, risk acceptance workflow, compensating control library, exception review automation

solutions.title: Security Posture Self-Assessment Tool
solutions.description: Deploy quarterly self-assessment surveys to identify fight-flight tendencies early
solutions.implementation: Create assessment questionnaires for security teams and executives detecting fight-flight patterns. Engage external security advisors to provide objective feedback on organizational security stance balance. Implement action planning for identified imbalances.
solutions.technical_controls: Survey automation platform, response analysis tools, external advisor coordination system, action plan tracking

risk_scenarios.title: Insider Threat Exploitation
risk_scenarios.description: Fight posture organizations focus intensively on external perimeters while trusted employees operate with excessive privileges and minimal monitoring
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Disgruntled employee or compromised insider account leveraging weak internal controls
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Fight posture creates insider threat blind spots through external threat fixation
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Organizations with fortress mentality missing Edward Snowden-style insider data theft

risk_scenarios.title: Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) Campaigns
risk_scenarios.description: APT actors exploit flight posture organizations using low-and-slow techniques that avoid triggering minimal security monitoring
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Patient reconnaissance and lateral movement exploiting avoidance-driven security gaps
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Flight posture delays threat investigation allowing extended attacker dwell time
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Organizations delaying investigation of suspicious activity allowing APT groups months of access

risk_scenarios.title: Business Email Compromise (BEC) Attacks
risk_scenarios.description: Flight organizations avoid implementing strong email security to prevent business disruption; fight organizations block legitimate emails while missing sophisticated BEC
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Social engineering attacks exploiting either inadequate controls or alert fatigue
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Both postures create exploitable gaps - flight via avoidance, fight via noise
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Organizations with extreme DLP blocking business while BEC attacks succeed, or minimal email security enabling widespread compromise

risk_scenarios.title: Supply Chain Compromises
risk_scenarios.description: Fight organizations hastily cut vendor relationships after minor incidents disrupting business; flight organizations avoid vendor assessments entirely
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Compromised suppliers exploiting either reactive over-response or systematic avoidance
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Binary fight-flight thinking prevents nuanced vendor risk management
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Organizations either maintaining clearly compromised vendors (flight) or severing critical relationships reactively (fight)
